top_categories.workout_context: CIRREM's Illinois rolling farmland gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
CIRREM's Illinois farmland, Rolling gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 75 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic CIRREM's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before February.
75 miles on Illinois rolling farmland gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of CIRREM. Train it until it feels boring.
At CIRREM, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
When someone attacks on Illinois rolling farmland gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At CIRREM, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Base fitness for CIRREM. Without this, the hard workouts break you down instead of building you up.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 3,000ft of climbing on Illinois rolling farmland gravel does to your power file on race day.
Varied gradients on Illinois rolling farmland gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for CIRREM’s 75 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at CIRREM requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on illinois rolling farmland gravel to build confidence. Expect: illinois farmland, rolling gravel, regional event.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 75 miles of illinois rolling farmland gravel in Roubaix, Illinois.
